content: The 112th Congress used TPA authority to pass implementing bills for U.S. FTAs with Colombia, Panama, and South Korea in 2011. Other trade negotiations that may require TPA include the Doha Development Round, TPP, TTIP, and TISA. Congress has granted the President TPA/fast track authority for over 40 years. The Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) clarifies Congress's authority over trade policy and gives the President negotiating leverage. Earlier versions were bipartisan, but as trade negotiations became more complex, renewing TPA has become more controversial. The expiration of TPA raises questions about its renewal. The Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) is the result of decades of debate and cooperation between Congress and the executive branch. It reflects the constitutional powers of both branches and the need for flexibility in negotiating trade agreements. The partnership between Congress and the President on trade policy can be strengthened or strained based on political and economic conditions. Congress has the authority to regulate foreign trade, while TPA gives the President negotiating leverage. The Constitution assigns no specific responsibility for trade to the President, but grants exclusive authority to negotiate treaties and international agreements. Congress historically set tariff rates on imported products for the first 150 years of the United States, with tariffs being the main trade policy instrument and revenue source. Trade debates in Congress often pitted northern manufacturing regions against southern commodity exporting regions. In the 1930s, the President's role in trade policy was to negotiate treaties for MFN treatment. The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930 drastically changed US trade policy by imposing high tariffs, leading to retaliatory tariffs and worsening the Great Depression. The Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act of 1934 (RTAA) authorized the President to enter into reciprocal trade agreements reducing tariffs within pre-approved levels, aiming to lessen political pressure from special interests faced by Congress. This act followed the damaging effects of the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in the 1930s, which worsened the Great Depression. The Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act was the last general tariff legislation passed by Congress, now only applied to imports from Cuba and North Korea. Congress delegated tariff-cutting authority but retained broader trade authority, subjecting trade agreements to periodic review and renewal. Tariff levels declined, reducing their significance as trade barriers. The establishment of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1947 shifted trade negotiations from bilateral to multilateral, expanding beyond tariffs. The Trade Expansion Act of 1962 granted the President authority to negotiate tariff reductions and required congressional review of agreements. This allowed the conclusion of the GATT Kennedy Round (1963-1967) focusing on tariff reduction. During the GATT Kennedy Round, agreements were reached on nontariff barriers, including customs valuation and antidumping practices. Congress opposed these agreements as they required changes beyond tariff modifications, leading to a debate on presidential authority. During the Kennedy Round, Congress debated granting the President authority to negotiate trade agreements, leading to the creation of fast track authority in the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Act of 1974 granted the President authority to enter trade agreements reducing tariffs. Implementing legislation for nontariff barrier agreements had to be passed by Congress. Concerns were raised about the impact of congressional debate and amendment procedures on trade negotiations. The Trade Act of 1974 allowed the President to negotiate trade agreements with limited congressional debate and amendment. Congress agreed to give trade agreements expedited treatment, with implementing bills subject to time-limited debate and no amendments. The Trade Act of 1974 allowed for expedited trade agreement negotiations with limited congressional debate and no amendments. Congress required the executive branch to consult with relevant committees and notify Congress before signing agreements. The Trade Act of 1974 also accredited 10 Members of Congress as advisers to the U.S. delegation of negotiators, expanding on the previous provision of five advisers in the Trade Act of 1962. This established the "fast track trade negotiating authority" which led to the conclusion of the Tokyo Round of the GATT (1973-1979) resulting in agreements on non-tariff barriers. The Trade Agreements Act of 1979 established expedited legislative procedures for trade agreements authority, which have remained unchanged since 1974. These provisions, found in Sections 151-154 of the Trade Act of 1974, have no sunset provisions but are subject to time limits. Congress extended the presidential authority to proclaim tariff modifications until January 2, 1982, along with implementing the Tokyo Round agreements. The Trade Agreements Act of 1979 extended presidential authority for trade agreements until January 2, 1988, focusing on reducing tariffs and addressing nontariff barriers. It added provisions for negotiating bilateral free trade agreements, including the U.S.-Israel and U.S.-Canada FTAs. The act waived the 90-day notification requirement for the U.S.-Israel FTA but mandated notification to Congress for negotiations with other countries. The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act (OTCA) extended the President's authority to enter into trade agreements before June 1, 1993, but only allowed expedited procedures for agreements entered into before June 1, 1991. Agreements leading to significant tariff changes required congressional approval through implementing legislation. Congress extended the authority and implementing procedures with H.R. 1876 in July 1993. In July 1993, the authority for trade agreements was extended until April 16, 1994, solely for the Uruguay Round. The law did not change any other aspects of the fast track authority. Congress did not approve new authority until the Trade Act of 2002. In 1997 and 1998, there were unsuccessful attempts to renew fast track authority. The bill for new trade agreements authority failed to pass (180-243) due to disagreements on negotiating objectives for labor and environmental issues. The WTO did not launch new negotiations in 1999, making renewal of trade agreements authority less of a priority. In 2001, President George W. Bush requested a renewal of fast track authority, renamed as "trade promotion authority (TPA)." The legislation renamed fast track authority to "trade promotion authority (TPA)" in the Bipartisan Trade Promotion Authority Act of 2002. TPA included new language for labor and environmental provisions but did not mandate minimal enforceable labor standards in trade agreements, leading to opposition from labor groups and some Members of Congress. The act also established the Congressional Oversight Group for congressional consultation. The original House version of the BPTA (H.R. 3005) passed by one vote (215-214) along party lines. It was combined in the Senate with other trade-related acts and passed as the Trade Act of 2002. Under this act, Congress approved implementing legislation for various Free Trade Agreement countries. The proposed BCTPA was introduced in 2015 by Senators Hatch and Wyden (S. 995). The BCTPA legislation, introduced in 2015 by Senators Hatch and Wyden, was modeled on previous trade acts. It was reported by the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee in April 2015. The legislation passed in May 2015 with updated negotiating objectives on trade in goods, services, agriculture, and intellectual property. The TPA-2015 legislation covers various trade aspects such as agriculture, intellectual property rights, regulatory practices, and digital trade. It includes provisions on labor, environment, currency manipulation, localization, state-owned enterprises, and human rights. TPA-2015 may be used for ongoing negotiations like TPP, T-TIP, and TISA. If not extended, TPA-2015 will expire on July 1, 2021. The European Union is involved in plurilateral trade negotiations for agreements like TISA and EGA to promote services and environmental goods trade. The congressional consultation process is a key part of Trade Promotion Authority (TPA), requiring the President to notify and consult with Congress before and after entering into trade agreements. The effectiveness of the congressional consultation process for trade negotiations under Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) has been questioned. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) found that despite extensive consultations with Congress on Free Trade Agreements (FTAs), many congressional staff felt they were not given enough time to provide input, meetings were more like briefings than consultations, and last-minute changes to draft FTA texts were not always included.
